Exaggerate: The claim may be seen as exaggerating the significance of the several hundred million dollars saved on the awarded contracts, considering the overall cost of the high-speed rail project.
Understate: The claim may understate the potential cost overruns and challenges faced by the California High-Speed Rail Authority, as indicated by the consultant's draft report suggesting an additional $8 billion in costs for a specific stretch of the rail network.
Lack enough support: The claim lacks sufficient evidence or data to support the assertion that the awarded contracts have come in several hundred million dollars below estimates. More information or documentation would be needed to verify this claim.
Problematic assumption: The claim assumes that the savings from the awarded contracts will translate into overall cost savings for the high-speed rail project, which may not necessarily be the case.
Exist alternative explanation: There may be alternative explanations for the lower-than-estimated bids, such as changes in market conditions, competition among contractors, or potential compromises in project scope or quality.
